image.altText: A stylised map shows Australia's 150 federal electorates as clusters of hexagons, with an animated change of colour

props.synopsis: The electoral maths on Saturday seems simple — win 76 seats and you win government. But that's not all there is to it.

title.children: Labor and Coalition paths to victory mapped

image.altText: M1 chaos map

props.synopsis: Emergency crews are responding to a major incident on the Sydney-bound motorway as hundreds of drivers stop with flat tyres caused by shards of metal on the road.

title.children: Breaking: 'Pandemonium' on the M1 as metal shards shred tyres

image.altText: Mike Waltz wears a checked shirt and cold-weather jacket.

props.synopsis: The Trump adviser responsible for the Signal group chat that became a national security scandal is being replaced and nominated as the next US ambassador at the United Nations.

title.children: Trump ousts 'Signalgate' national security adviser Mike Waltz

image.altText: two male politicians wearing suits at a park

props.synopsis: The Coalition enters the dying hours of the 2025 election campaign defending its budget against charges from some of the nation's top economists that it erodes the Coalition's self-declared legacy of fiscal responsibility.

title.children: Voter 'bribes' send Taylor 'off brand' with bigger deficits, say budget experts

image.altText: a blue corflute that's been burnt and attached to a pole

props.synopsis: Candidates have seen their election signs marked with swastikas or offensive slurs, burned, vandalised, smeared with excrement, stomped on and shredded.

title.children: Burned, defaced and shredded: Are Australia’s corflute wars getting worse?

image.altText: A mural dedicated to the Australian women killed by domestic violence in 2024 and 2025

props.synopsis: Violence against women has stirred outrage among voters and politicians have promised to do something about it. Their policy proposals tell a different story, write Heidi Davoren and Mary Lloyd

title.children: It's the 'national crisis' that neither party has been able to solve

image.altText: A graphic of Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton cut-outs

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton begin their final full day of campaigning ahead of Saturday's federal election, with both leaders looking to make last-minute inroads with undecided voters. Follow live.

title.children: Dutton says 'we're in for the fight of our lives' as leaders begin final push

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: PM says his government would give peacekeeping force in Ukraine consideration
PM says 'hiding' shadow ministers an issue for Dutton
'I'm working my guts out to ensure a majority government tomorrow': PM

image.altText: Independent teal MPs Zali Steggall Kate Chaney Allegra PSender

props.synopsis: Several key independent MPs say if they are returned to parliament on May 3 and neither Labor nor the Coalition win an outright majority, they will seek a review of Australia's tax base through a "broad-ranging" process, saying the "taboo" on tax must end.

title.children: Independents would push to end 'taboo' on tax reform in hung parliament

image.altText: A dentist wearing a face mask places a tube inside a patient's mouth.

props.synopsis: Two thirds of Australian dental practitioners recently surveyed support expanding Medicare to include subsidised dental services, with many reporting patients are struggling to afford oral healthcare.

title.children: Dentists back calls to expand Medicare as cost of living bites

image.altText: Side profile of a middle-aged white woman with long brown hair standing in a dark-lit situation room near abstract screens.

props.synopsis: Scientists and legal experts warn against commercial deep-sea mining as US President Donald Trump signs an executive order opening up both US and international waters.

title.children: Trump moves world a step closer to commercial deep-sea mining

image.altText: The two men standing shoulder to shoulder, Pope Francis does not look amused

props.synopsis: The conclave will be a "fight for the soul of the Catholic Church" between those who saw promise in the modernising changes Pope Francis made and those "who hated him for it".

title.children: The secret MAGA battle for dominance in the Catholic church

image.altText: A close up composite photo of Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese at the debate.

props.synopsis: When we look back, we can see the road to election day has had a multitude of signposts, flashing red lights, twists, turns and potholes.

title.children: Key markers on the bumpy road to this federal election

image.altText: two women

props.synopsis: RecipeTin Eats founder Nagi Maehashi calls for an end to the "trolling" of baking sensation Brooke Bellamy, after accusing her of plagiarism.

title.children: RecipeTin Eats founder pleads with fans to 'stop trolling' Brooke Bellamy

image.altText: An Amazon package sits on a doorstep.

props.synopsis: US stocks continue to reclaim ground from their post-tariff losses, with the S&P 500 gaining for an eighth straight session to reach its highest level since April 2. Amazon's shares fell in extended trade. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Amazon disappoints Wall St amid tariff uncertainty

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Apple expects tariffs to cost it $1.4 billion
Amazon disappoints with cloud revenue missing expectations
US stocks continue streak of gains

image.altText: People walk on a pier in front of Singapore's merlion statue and the city's skyline

props.synopsis: It calls itself a democracy, yet the wealthy city-state has had the same ruling party since 1959. That is unlikely to change anytime soon.

title.children: Singapore's election is also on Saturday — but we already know the outcome

image.altText: Albanese stands in the middle of a group of children, he's looking to the side with palms pressed together in greeting

props.synopsis: As Albanese and Dutton crisscrossed the country aiming to win over voters, ABC photographers were there to capture the best images of the campaign.

title.children: Two wannabe PMs, a media pack and the search for gold

image.altText: Queensland and NSW players Julia Robinson and Jaime Chapman contest for the ball in the air during State of Origin.

props.synopsis: Eye gouges, hair pulls, a classic duel and a glorious night for the new kids on the block. Here are five quick hits from the Women's State of Origin series opener.

title.children: Five quick hits: A classic duel and a hair pull in Origin opener

image.altText: A close up shot of Donald Trump looking at Xi Jinping.

props.synopsis: The post linked to state-run media said that the US had reached out through multiple channels hoping to discuss its tariff policy with Beijing.

title.children: A Chinese state media post points to a softening in the US-China trade war

image.altText: A headshot of Diddy wearing a white suit, standing in front of a grey background

props.synopsis: Sean "Diddy" Combs tells a US federal court hearing he rejected prosecutors' offer for a plea deal ahead of facing trial over racketeering conspiracy and sex trafficking charges.

title.children: 'Diddy' rejects plea deal ahead of sex trafficking trial

image.altText: A person wearing a dark jacket and tan pants holding a green rectangular Harrods retail bag

props.synopsis: London department store Harrods says hackers have attempted to break into its systems, in the third such high-profile cyber attack on a UK-based retailer in a fortnight.

title.children: Harrods becomes latest UK retailer hit by cyber attack

image.altText: An astronaut in a white spacesuit floating horizontally above part of the International Space Station

props.synopsis: NASA astronauts Colonel Anne McClain and Major Nichole Ayers leave the International Space Station for almost 6 hours to to move an antenna and prepare the station for new solar panels.

title.children: Astronauts conduct fifth all-female spacewalk

image.altText: A close up photo of Erin Patterson looking over her shoulder wearing glases.

props.synopsis: Erin Patterson's estranged husband tells a court he thought she loved his family in the lead-up to their deaths from eating a poisonous beef Wellington she had cooked.

title.children: Simon Patterson tells court of 'strained' relationship with alleged mushroom killer

image.altText: A woman fills out a ballot.

props.synopsis: The federal election result could be known while Western Australians are still scrambling to the polling booth. But in a close race, sandgropers could once again hold the keys to the Lodge.

title.children: Could West Australians again hold the keys to the Lodge?

image.altText: A woman with short, light hair, smiling outdoors.

props.synopsis: Queanbeyan-Palerang Regional Council is auctioning two dozen properties to recover unpaid rates. But local Gina Greentree says the council has bungled the process, with the farmer bidding for a lot she thought she owned.

title.children: Property of man dead for 65 years among lots auctioned for unpaid rates

image.altText: Police officers in uniform patrolling a street.

props.synopsis: Just 57 Tasmanian children are responsible for half of all youth crime in the state, data shows, with a senior police officer saying the "therapeutic" approach won't work for some kids.

title.children: 57 kids 'responsible' for half of youth crime across Tasmania, data shows

image.altText: A tall fence with razor wire attached at the bottom and top. Blue sky and some jail buildings in the background.

props.synopsis: Overcrowding in the Alice Springs jail has contributed to a $460,000 repair bill at the facility, with pressure on the NT's prisons only set to grow after the introduction of tough new bail laws.

title.children: Overcrowding, riots blamed for $460k repairs at Alice Springs jail

image.altText: Rows of vineyards stretch across golden plains, seen through the leaves of a tree in the foreground.

props.synopsis: The need for development in the region is clear, but the Barossa Valley's major stakeholders disagree about the way it needs to be done.

title.children: The Barossa Valley is being pushed in many different directions – but where will it end up?

image.altText: A pile of study materials, with a woman working on a computer visible in the background.

props.synopsis: Donna Edwards is so close to fulfilling her lifelong dream of becoming a qualified psychologist, but says limited postgraduate course availability means it's "almost impossible" to reach the finish line.

title.children: Why is it 'almost impossible' for psychology students to get qualified?

image.altText: woman wearing blue shirt leans on fence with paddock and animals behind

props.synopsis: Students at a NSW school have been issued bottled water while the source of lead and copper found during routine testing is investigated.

title.children: Neurologist concerned after lead discovered in school's water

image.altText: Indoor salmon farming facility with a series of tanks.

props.synopsis: In Canada, the government has committed to transition marine salmon farming near British Columbia to onshore operations by 2029. Tasmanian Greens want the state government to follow suit, but the salmon industry says it's a case of "voodoo economics".

title.children: The Greens say land-based salmon farming is viable. The Tasmanian industry says otherwise

image.altText: Cars stalled in morning peak hour traffic in Annerley, Brisbane

props.synopsis: All Queensland government fees and charges, including vehicle registration, will be hiked by 3.4 per cent from next financial year.

title.children: Vehicle rego and driver's licence costs to rise as Queensland hikes fees

image.altText: Three birs walking along a grassy patch of the wetlands

props.synopsis: Australian Consolidated Gold has withdrawn its bid to drill for copper and gold near the Macquarie Marshes in NSW, prompting calls for tougher scrutiny of mining approvals in ecologically sensitive areas.

title.children: Graziers seek stronger protections after wetlands mining bid withdrawn

image.altText: planet ark kids

props.synopsis: Planet Ark Environmental Foundation, one of Australia's largest environmental non-for-profits, has entered voluntary administration following a review of its "financial position and future viability".

title.children: Environmental not-for-profit Planet Ark goes into voluntary administration

image.altText: A missile the size of several cars is towed on the back of a truck down a street lined with onlookers

props.synopsis: Experts say a military conflict between the nuclear neighbours is almost guaranteed. When nukes are involved, escalation is a possibility the world takes seriously. What are the odds of it going that far?

title.children: Experts weigh in on possibility of war between nuclear powers

image.altText: An elderly woman

props.synopsis: Ethel Caterham says her secret to long life is "never arguing with anyone".

title.children: British great-grandma named world's oldest person after Brazilian nun dies
